title: coronavirus cases uk worldwide second wave
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Major outbreaks across Asia and South America contributed to a record high number of global casesThe number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the UK has passed 300,000 amid a surge in new infections globally.Data from John Hopkins University revealed that there have been 301,935 cases of Covid-19 in the UK, though the number of new daily cases has fallen significantly in recent weeks.By contrast, major outbreaks across Asia and South America contributed to a record high number of new cases around the world on Thursday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFigures compiled by Oxford-based research group OurWorldinData revealed 176,426 new cases globally, taking the total number of cases to 8.46 million.The actual figure is likely to be significantly higher due to limited testing.The UK’s falling infection rate prompted the government to lower the virus alert level from four to three.This means that Covid-19 is now considered to be in “general circulation” but transmission is no longer “high or rising exponentially”.The number of new deaths from the virus has also levelled off in recent weeks, in tandem with the number of new cases.The UK has the fifth highest number of coronavirus cases globally, behind the US, Brazil, Russia and India.When measured in terms of new daily cases, however, the UK ranks 18th in the world.The spike in new infections comes mostly from Brazil, the US, India, Russia, Pakistan, Chile and Mexico, which account for more than half of all new infections.Other countries to experience an upswing in new cases include Iran, Saudi Arabia and Turkey, following a resurgence of the virus in the Middle East.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: help the hungry food face mask donation virustatic
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.New virus shields maintain effectiveness for hundreds of hours of wearThousands of face coverings are being delivered along with fresh produce to charities and vulnerable people for our Help The Hungry campaign.The innovation comes thanks to a donation by Virustatic Limited of 10,000 face coverings to The Felix Project, our appeal partner, just as non-essential retail begins to open and it becomes mandatory to wear face coverings on public transport.The Virustatic Shield coverings feature a protective protein called Viruferrin that has been developed and tested by experts for more than a decade. Viruferrin has been scientifically proven to block 98 per cent of similar viruses to Covid-19, including influenza and Sars.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe snood-like coverings can be worn for up to 50 hours before they need washing, and their effectiveness only drops to 96 per cent after over 200 hours of wear.The face coverings are cut and sewn together by Cookson &amp Clegg in Blackburn, which is run by Patrick Grant, star of the Great British Sewing Bee. He is also behind a campaign to get Britons making their own coverings, The Great Community Sew.How to support our campaignThe coverings, which retail at £20, are different to medical grade PPE used by NHS workers. However, due to the protein coverings they are more effective than standard face masks at protecting wearers from viruses.There was a buzz at the Royal Park Felix Project depot when boxes of Virustatic Shield coverings arrived.David Clark, who has been volunteering for three years, said: “I think it is important to wear these face coverings when you’re delivering to members of the public who potentially come into contact with vulnerable people.”Mr Clark dropped off some coverings to Ian Breen, centre manager at Acton Homeless Concern, which serves hot meals five days a week to those in temporary accommodation or on the streets. Mr Breen said: “It is fantastic to have a delivery of some masks for free. It is important to protect those working here and the people who use our centre.”Gretchen Fisher, from Ealing, who has been volunteering for four years, added: “I wear them whenever I go out as you have to protect others.” Mantas Keblis, the depot manager, said that having “extra precautions” would help food reach more people in London. “Everyone really likes them. They are very comfortable to wear.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailJohn Butcher, operations director of Virustatic Shield, said: “The Felix Project has never been more important.“Reducing food waste while also providing much-needed meals was a no-brainer to get involved with.“The donation of 10,000 Virustatic Shields will hopefully mean that 10,000 iniduals are not only fed but protected so they can freely move across London.”Since the outbreak of the pandemic, my team at Cookson &amp Clegg in Blackburn have been working to produce hundreds of thousands of scrubs, gowns and more recently face coverings for the NHS, for social care workers and the general public.As soon as I heard about Help The Hungry and the work it was doing, I wanted to help. And today, because of the enormous generosity of Virustatic Shield, whose innovative anti-viral snoods we’ve also been producing, 10,000 of London’s most vulnerable people will receive a vital face covering, delivered to them via The Independent’s fantastic campaign.Which star will you bid for in Peter Blake’s big hotel cover auction?Help the Hungry: Our readers help us reach £6.5mHow Help The Hungry is helping refugees forced to live on £5 a day It is now mandatory to wear face coverings on public transport, but these coverings are in short supply.That’s why we started The Big Community Sew to encourage people to make face coverings for their friends and neighbours, and by doing so preserve vital supplies of PPE for NHS workers and care home staff who are fighting this virus on the frontline.The science behind face coverings is simple: they help prevent the wearer from unwittingly spreading the disease. So put simply, if I wear one I protect you, if you wear one you protect me.Patrick Grant is a star of television’s ‘Great British Sewing Bee’The Independent is encouraging readers to help groups that are trying to feed the hungry during the crisis – find out how you can help here. title: help the hungry fundraiser artwork sir peter blake bid
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'I’m very glad that maybe my left eyebrow has gone to good use,' says Dame Judi DenchThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Dame Judi Dench and Joanna Lumley are among the stars who have today urged Londoners to bid on sections of Sir Peter Blake’s pop artwork Our Fans to raise money for Help the Hungry.Last Friday, The Independent announced that the giant mural — draped over the London Mandarin Oriental hotel in Knightsbridge during its 2017 renovation — would be cut into 100 sections and auctioned off.The work, which echoes Sir Peter’s famous 1967 artwork for The Beatles’ Sgt Pepper album, is his largest piece, the size of 38 London buses. Each section features a famous face, including Morgan Freeman, Whoopi Goldberg and Sir Paul McCartney, and is signed by Sir Peter, 87.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesProceeds will go to two beneficiaries, including The Independent's Help The Hungry Now appeal partner The Felix Project.Today, Ms Lumley said it was an “honour” to be part of the fundraising effort. She said: “Double honour — to be a face in Peter Blake’s awesome collage for the Mandarin and to be a tiny part of helping Help the Hungry. It is a fabulous way of making life worth living.”Help the Hungry: Our readers help us reach £6.5mDame Judi said: “How wonderful that Peter Blake’s amazing artwork will have a new lease of life for such good causes. I’m very glad that maybe my left eyebrow has gone to good use.”Italian actress Caterina Murino, who also stars in the work, said: “The world is upside down. We fight for our life, we fight for the life of our brothers, and this is the feeling I have when I contemplate Sir Peter Blake’s masterpiece! A hundred stars that reflect the ersity of our world fighting to help Help the Hungry. title: help the hungry school children meals felix project ocado
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'These generous new donations take us 70 per cent of the way towards our goal to secure £10m to combat food poverty in London over the next three years,' says The Independent's Evgeny LebedevThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Our Help The Hungry appeal today passed the £7m mark, enabling our appeal partner, The Felix Project, to deliver the equivalent of 4.3 million meals to hungry schoolchildren and vulnerable Londoners in the 12 weeks since lockdown began.The milestone was reached thanks to more significant corporate donations, including an additional £100,000 from online grocer Ocado, taking its total donation to £390,000, and a further £90,000 from banking group Citi boosting their aggregate give to £250,000.It comes as the charity Feeding Britain warns that 3 million children face the prospect of hunger during the upcoming school holidays. Of these, it cautions, only 1 million are eligible for the government’s free school meal summer holiday voucher of £15 a week, with the remaining 2 million living with parents who narrowly do not qualify but cannot always afford food.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHelen Barnard, of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, confirmed that the summer voucher scheme – agreed by the prime minister after being forced into a U-turn by footballer Marcus Rashford – only covers a minority of children in poverty. She said: “Soaring numbers of families are being pulled under and having to rely on food banks to get through the current crisis, even with the voucher scheme in place.”The harsh reality is that an astounding 66 per cent of food-insecure families – amounting to almost 200,000 children in London – cannot access government help and are forced to rely on food parcels from charities such as The Felix Project.Food and 10,000 face coverings donated to charities and vulnerableWhich star will you bid for in Peter Blake’s big hotel cover auction?Help the Hungry: Our readers help us reach £6.5mHow Help The Hungry is helping refugees forced to live on £5 a day At the start of lockdown, The Felix Project faced an existential crisis with a total collapse of its fundraising. Thanks to The Independent’s campaign, it has not only been able to survive but has operated at twice its normal capacity, delivering up to 40 tons of nutritious produce a day and supplying 86 schools and 400 charities and community hubs across the capital over the course of a week.The Independent shareholder Evgeny Lebedev said: “These generous new donations take us 70 per cent of the way towards our goal to secure £10m to combat food poverty in London over the next three years. Our pledge is given added urgency by the release of worrying economic data, including that the number of people out of work and claiming benefits jumped 23 per cent to 2.8 million last month.”Jo West, of Ocado Retail, said most of its donation had been raised from Ocado and their customers via their “you give, we give” scheme. She added: “We’re extremely grateful to our customers for their generosity which enables groups like The Felix Project to bring food to people in desperate need.” James Murray, chair of the Bridgepoint Charitable Trust, which donated £50,000, said: “We are delighted to contribute to the work of The Felix Project in feeding vulnerable communities.”Help the hungry&nbsp|&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: liverpool fans celebrate winning premiership league anfield
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Supporters defy coronavirus restrictions to flood into city and descend on stadium to toast an end to three decades of hurtThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.In the end, perhaps, this wasn’t exactly as Liverpool fans would have dreamed it: with the city’s pubs closed, with the stadium shut up, with their team not even playing.The club won its first football league title in 30 years on Thursday night after rivals Man City lost to Chelsea.But, if it was a slightly surreal climax to a wholly surreal season, it did little to dampen celebrations here.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAn estimated 2,000 supporters turned up at Anfield bearing flags, fireworks and flares, while hundreds more piled into city centre parks and squares. Cars could be heard beeping all across the city. A cardboard cutout of manager Jurgen Klopp was doing a roaring trade in being hugged.They knew, fans said, they were stretching coronavirus lockdown rules to their absolute limits. They knew they were ignoring the calls of both manager Jurgen Klopp and local authorities to toast the success at home. But this was a moment in their city’s history, they argued, that was simply too big to be experienced on the sofa.Watch Liverpool’s players celebrate the moment they won the title“Pandemic or not, mate, I’m 21 and this is the first time I’ve seen Liverpool win the title – so no way am I staying at home,” said Michael Pinnington, a 21-year-old railway worker, four pints in and preparing for a long and loud night. “It’s dampened it a little bit, what’s happened. But ... we’ve won the league. Nothing can spoil that. It means everything to me. I’ve been waiting for it my whole life.”He himself was out with five or six mates. “Can you imagine if this was normal times?” asked one, Jo Stewart, also 21 and a railway worker. “The whole city would be here.”“Fair play, mate,” came the instant reply. “Three quarters of the city.”It was not just Anfield where people gathered. The city’s famously lively Concert Square got so busy as the night progressed that police moved in to move people on – something they did not do later at Anfield – while crowds also took over Sefton Park and Chavasse Park.At the latter, located by the city’s waterfront, groups sat in pre-chalked out socially distanced circles, listening to radios, refreshing Internet feeds, and watching on buffeting mobile screens. Once or twice, they burst into a rendition of ‘You’ll Never Walk Alone’. Drinks were sprayed into the air as at news of Chelsea goals.“It’s not exactly the normal, but there’s nowhere else I’d rather be right now,” said Mo Abdul, a 25-year-old research and development scientist. “I took the afternoon off work today just to spend time in the city and soak it up. Days like this don’t come along very often.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailA pause. “Although hopefully they’ll come along more often in future.”The reason, above all else perhaps, that this was so special: the fact it ended that three-decade wait for the title.When Liverpool last won the league, the Premiership did not yet exist, Sky Sports was going by the name The Sports Channel and didn’t show football, and only five members of the current squad had been born. Back then, they were the most successful club in English football history and had finished in the top two every year, bar one, since 1973. Safe to say, no one here – indeed, no one anywhere – saw a sudden 30-year hiatus happening.“It’s been a burden,” said builder Andy Boylett. “I was six when we won that last title. I remember it but only just. And the city has been in the shadow of that ever since.”How so? “Because Liverpool is famous for football – other things too but football – and for having this great club. And, for most of those 30 years, we haven’t been great. That’s hard to deal with. It’s hard to be in the shadow of the past.”The moment, now it had come, he said, was strange, nonetheless.“Obviously, the gap in the season and games being played behind closed doors, it’s not exactly how you’d want it, is it?” he said. “But it doesn’t matter in the end. We’ve won it, that’s the most important thing. It won’t say anything about coronavirus in the history books. It will just say champions.”More to the point, says Adam Lally, with just the hint of a wink, fans got to celebrate more traditionally last year after the club won the Champions League.“Everyone was getting good and bendy in the pubs then,” the 19-year-old apprentice remembers. “The bus parade, brilliant. So, we’ve done that. Tonight, fine, we’ll do it all outside. Glorious weather anyway.”He was, he said, as happy as he could ever remember being. “Mate, I want to say it’s better than giving birth but I’ve never done that. So, until I do, I reckon this might be as good as it gets. It’s boss. Absolutely boss.”His friend, student Aiysha Griffiths agreed. “I can’t put it into word, really. I’m speechless. I’ve had my dad talking about the old glory days all my life. Now, at last, I know how it feels.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: pubs coronavirus uk reopen 4 july lockdown
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘We wouldn’t be able to serve a pint on the bar very easily,’ one landlord saysThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Landlord Katie Martin could find space for just four tables in her pub – which can usually hold more than 100 people – under new government rules.The Globe’s capacity would drop to a “whopping 16”, she tells The Independent.The pub owner in the Berkshire market town of Newbury says their inside space is too long and narrow to be able to fit many people in a socially distanced way – even with a relaxed one-metre rule.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“It isn’t a viable business to run,” she says.Martin says The Globe, which sits right in the centre of Newbury, will not reopen on 4 July – when pubs across England have been given the green light to welcome customers back in a socially distanced way after months of closure due to coronavirus. What are the UK lockdown rules now?How to ease yourself back into socialising once lockdown liftsThe new lost generationWhich countries are seeing a second wave of coronavirus?How to wear a face mask safelyNeither will Platform 3 in Surrey, a tiny pub next to a train station which claims to be the smallest in the UK.“We wouldn’t be able to have people social distancing inside the pub. We could probably have about 10 to 15 people sitting outside,” Alex Coomes, founder of Brightwater Brewery – whose brewery tap is the Claygate micropub – says. “For us, that is not profitable,” he tells The Independent. “So we have decided not to open for sales.”Pubs were ordered shut in late March due to the coronavirus outbreak, with the government saying earlier this week English establishments can open their doors again in early July as long as they follow certain precautions.Up until now, pubs have been finding other ways to survive, such as by doing takeout service – like The Globe – or door-to-door service. Coomes from Platform 3 says he has been driving around his local area dropping beer at houses – sometimes getting an emotional welcome. “When this all kicked off, I was delivering beers to people and they would burst into tears because they hadn’t seen anybody all week,” he tells The Independent. Meanwhile in Suffolk, The Nutshell, another tiny pub, is hoping to be get permission to sell drinks to people standing outside. Until then, one of the landlords tells The Independent it is ”not really feasible” for his establishment – with an inside space of 15ft by 7ft – to reopen, even with the relaxed rules in early July. “We wouldn’t be able to serve a pint on the bar very easily,” Geoff Page from the Bury St Edmunds pub explains.“The member of staff would have to step back from the bar for the customer to get up from the seat on the edge of the pub to collect the pint.”He estimates the pub would be able to fit five single people inside – all sitting on their on their own – under the social distancing rules, which say people must stay at least one metre apart as a preventative measure against Covid-19. “Our unique selling point – the size of us – happens to be the Achilles heel in this particular situation,” Page says. Martin says they have been told they can serve people outside between 10am to 5pm. “Which is great,” she tells The Independent,” but that’s not when I have any business. I have business in the evening.” Outdoor space has been key for The Rake, a small pub in central London, to plan its reopening on 4 July. The establishment in Borough Market has been open as an off-licence throughout lockdown, with people queueing up in their gardens for takeaway beer – with draught beer poured into an open can, then sealed using a machine on the bar, as an option. When will pubs, cinemas, restaurants and hairdressers be open from?Pubs to offer al fresco dining and takeaway pints under new billOne of Britain’s smallest pubs on reopening during coronavirus“Our small garden is going to be used for customers,” manager George Aldridge tells The Independent. ”We are going to be introducing table service and table bookings – which we have never done before.” Mike Hill, the founder of Utobeer which runs the London pub, tells The Independent: “I think if we didn’t have outside space, and somebody told us we couldn’t use outside space, I would probably seriously consider not opening.”The small size of the pub means customers will not be allowed to drink inside, he adds. While some pubs will be planning to welcome back people in a socially-distanced environment on 4 July, others – including smaller ones – have decided to wait a bit longer. Coomes from Platform 3 in Claygate says his tiny pub – which can fit just one person inside – cannot afford the extra costs that would come with reopening during the pandemic, such as having a person manning the toilets. “I can’t justify having someone do that in my micropub,” he says. ”The figures don’t add up for us.”Speaking about pubs being able to reopen on new conditions, the landlord of The Nutshell – which is thought to be one of the smallest pubs in the UK – tells The Independent: “It is not going to change really very much at all for ourselves at all.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - disastrous no-deal Brexit at the end of the year has been rejected by the UK’s chief negotiator.With the talks deadlocked, it was thought the EU could agree to give the UK the ability to break free for future conflict in the relationship – but had welcomed what it viewed as new-found flexibility in London.After clashes following recent remote negotiations, optimism had crept up that an agreement title: chlorinated chicken brexit us trade deal hormone beef
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'Dual tariff' plan raised in&nbspWashington allowing US food producers to sell products that does not comply with British standards if they pay higher leviesThe environment secretary has said laws barring chlorinated chicken and hormone-fed beef won't change to secure a trade deal with the US - despite a previous pledge to maintain the ban being dropped by No 10.George Eustice said the UK was not under any obligation to change its approach amid concerns from farmers and campaigners that the government could lower standards on imported produce as part of trade with the US.Donald Trump's administration has made it clear that it will not allow American farmers to be disadvantaged in a US-UK trade deal, with US trade representative Robert Lighthizer describing concerns about farming practices as thinly veiled protectionism.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMinisters are said to have put forward a dual tariff plan to Washington, that would allow US food producers to sell products that does not comply with British standards if they paid higher levies.The move would mark a significant loosening of the current rules, where the UK complies with strict European welfare and sanitary standards.Minister won’t comment on chlorinated chicken, claiming US listeningAsked to guarantee that UK law would not change, Mr Eustice told the Today programme: I can't bind the hands of any future government, as you will know.This government is clear, we were the ones that brought across the prohibition on the use of washes such as chlorine and hormones in beef and we won't change that.Mr Eustice said the UK had to be open to considering approaches that other countries might bring to us under trading rules but we're not under any obligation to change it.He said the Conservatives had made a manifesto commit to protect food standards and animal welfare, which would be central to the ongoing trade talks.However his comments come after Liz Truss, the international trade secretary, refused to tell MPs about the proposed deal in case the US trade negotiators were listening.“I’m not going to go into detail in this committee on our negotiating strategy, because I suspect our counterparties from across the Atlantic might be taking account of my comments,” she said.Earlier this month, Downing Street dropped a pledge to maintain bans on chlorinated chicken and hormone-fed beef, as post-Brexit trade talks ramp up with Washington.The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: jenrick planning richmond desmond idan ofer tory donor
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Housing secretary also facing claims he met with another billionaire Tory donor while considering funding decision as treasury secretary in 2018The government wanted to give Robert Jenrick more power over planning decisions before the controversy erupted over his relationship with a billionaire property developer, according to reports.However, Boris Johnson has decided to put the proposals “on hold” rather than unveil them in a major speech about rebuilding Britain in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic, The Daily  claimed.The prime minister was also expected to include the changes in a white paper on planning later this year, the newspaper said.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAccording to the , the housing secretary would set up a system of development corporations with the power to take planning decisions usually made by local councils.These corporations would also be able to buy land with public money, grant planning permission and then sell the land to developers at a profit.Boris Johnson has ‘full confidence’ in Robert Jenrick, says No 10Minister denies Jenrick gave ‘special treatment’ to developerJenrick faces calls to resign over Tory donor rowHowever Downing Street described the claims as “not our policy”, and said there was no link between the current controversy and the decision to put the plans on hold. When contacted by The Independent, No10 said it had nothing to add.Mr Jenrick is under mounting pressure to explain his apparent closeness to Tory donor Richmond Desmond in the weeks leading up to his decision to approve a £1bn development in Westferry, east London.The housing secretary is also facing claims he met another billionaire while considering a decision that would have a financial impact on their business.The  reported that the then-exchequer secretary to the Treasury met Israeli businessman Idan Ofer, the ultimate owner of the UK mining company Cleveland Potash, on 21 March 2018.At that time, Mr Jenrick was assessing whether to offer state support for a new potash mine being built by a rival company, Sirius Minerals, it is claimed.A spokesperson for Mr Jenrick said: “He recused himself from decisions on the Sirius Minerals project. title: schools england return coronavirus classrooms rules guidelines summer
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Secondary and primary school children&nbspare emerging from lockdown and back into classrooms. Here are some of the measures that schools are implementing to make the transition easier for pupils, staff and parentsIn association with the UK GovernmentHinchingbrooke School is an academy school in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, with more than 1,900 pupils and 200 staff. Teachers started welcoming back A-level students last week.“We’ve only had the Year 12s in so far, but for them it was really clear they were delighted to be back,” says Mark Patterson, school principal, pictured above. “You could see it on their faces. It’s getting back to some sense of routine, structure and normality.He continues: “I think a lot of them have been surprised by how much they’ve missed school. I think if you’d asked them before lockdown ‘Would you like a week off?’, they’d have said ‘Please!’. I bet if you asked them now, they’d say ‘Can I come back?’. I think the parents and students now realise how important school is.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesPrior to the return, teachers organised a virtual assembly for Year 10 and 12 pupils, and sent a booklet home detailing the new guidelines which would be in place.5 back-to-school tips for parents&nbsp“Don't give them a lot of small instructions – recognise your child would have had an enormous amount of&nbspinstructions during the course of the day.”“If you are rewarding your child's behaviour, it's very important to do it every time.”“For a child who's been finding it tough,&nbsptalking to another child who's been in the same situation is by far the best way of letting it out.”“It's important to encourage a child to work for themselves and get on with their own inner task.”New measures include red circles marked on the ground that are two metres apart and one-way systems throughout the school.“We’ve reorganised all the classrooms that we’re using so the desks and chairs are two metres apart,” Patterson explains. “We’ve got designated areas set aside at break and lunchtime for each group to go to, and we’ve got signage around the school reminding everybody of the importance of hygiene, frequent hand washing and keeping their distance.”Implementing new measuresRheeya Makwana is one of the Year 12 students who has returned to Hinchingbrooke. “We’ve been having online lessons and voiceover PowerPoints, but it’s not really the same as being in a classroom,” she says. “The structure was really good and I felt like I learned a lot more being back at school. I came home in such a good mood.”Rheeya’s father Yogesh Makwana did have some initial worries about his daughter returning to school: “There’s always some concern, but all the communication from school has been excellent in the build up to it and all the measures that have been put in place have reassured us. If you offered our 13-year-old the chance to go back to school tomorrow, he’d do it in a heartbeat. He misses his classes the social interaction. He loves PE and he does so much at school that he misses.Year 10 pupils Vahine and Lucia will also be returning to the school this week. “The twins are really looking forward to it,” says their mother, Alesia Dickinson. “They’ve been messaging all their friends to find out what group they’re in. Less than a week after we said yes to going back we found out what bubbles they were in and we had clear guidelines about times, rooms and what they can expect when they go back to school. They’re raring to go.”Both Makwana and Dickinson agree that their children have missed the structure of school lessons and that the transition back to the classroom has been easier than expected. “I think it’s a positive thing,” says Dickinson. “I think it’s a step in the right direction. We need to let the children start that process.”Going back to Embark schoolsTrust leader at Embark Matthew Crawford, pictured below, has been welcoming back primary pupils to the Federation’s schools across Derbyshire.“The feedback we have had so far from all the schools across the Trust is that it’s going really well in terms of welcoming the children back,” he says. “It’s not a one-size-fits-all. Each school has done a risk assessment based on what they can do.”Most Embark schools are now back at around 25-30 per cent capacity, Crawford says. It's up from around two per cent when lockdown began, when it was just key workers’ children and more vulnerable pupils in the classroom.“It’s lovely to hear the children playing and see schools becoming vibrant again,” he adds. “As soon as lockdown began, we started work on our Reconnection to Recovery and Resilience programme, a nine-stage support package to welcome children back safely.”Keyworker Vicki Ellis has two children who have returned to one of Embark's schools Richardson Endowed Primary - Amelia in Year 3 and Darcey in Year 1, pictured below.The first day the girls were back I was wondering how they were all day. I knew the school had done everything possible to welcome the children back in a happy, positive way but I worried whether Amelia and Darcey were enjoying themselves. But when they came home they were so happy to have had that day at school – and eager to go back next day. Crawford explains that the school has tried to make the transition back to the classroom as fun as possible for the children: “We’re following the guidelines but in a way that’s fun for the children. We aren’t marking big Xs on the floor. Some of our schools, for example, are painting snakes in bright colours to show the way.”Embark has also shared its programme with schools as far as Devon, Durham, South Gloucestershire and Wales.“It’s a suite of resources and activities that schools can adapt to their own settings, taking the bits that work for them,” explains Crawford. “It’s lovely that the brilliant work of our staff is making a difference and impacting the lives of millions of children across the country, not just the 3,000 within our Trust.”Information in this article applies to schools in England only. title: putin russia vote constitutional reform leader 2036
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The vote is deliberately being held in the grey zone,’ says one opposition activistThe Independent employs reporters around the world to bring you truly independent journalism. To support us, please consider a&nbspcontribution.Voting has begun across Russia on proposed constitutional reforms that would allow Vladimir Putin to rule until at least 2036.The vote is being brought to Russians via impromptu polling booths on park benches, on buses, in the boots of cars, in theatres and factories, and even in “hot zones” of Covid-19 hospitals. Voting will continue for an unprecedented seven days, and every day will see a lottery draw, raffling anything from supermarket vouchers to cars and apartments. Authorities insist that such creativity is a necessary response to the challenges posed in the era of the coronavirus. Opponents say the extraordinary measures to increase turnout demonstrate the unpopularity of Mr Putin’s decision to prioritise a power grab during a pandemic. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe vote, which was originally planned for 22 April before being rescheduled to this week, will ask Russians for a yes or no answer on over 200 new amendments to the country’s constitution.The most important of these proposed changes – the resetting of presidential term limits – has been routinely under-emphasised in voting literature, and in one case was even omitted. Official messages have concentrated instead on populist measures such as cementing marriage as a union of man and woman, emphasising the role of God, and guaranteeing indexation of pensions and other social payments. The vote is not a referendum per se the amendments have, in fact, already been passed by both parliaments. Pro-democracy groups say that the unclear classification of the vote is no accident. In a referendum, both sides are officially allowed to agitate for and against, and are entitled to airtime and finance. Not so in this campaign.  “The vote was specially set up to avoid any debate,” says Grigory Melkonyants, co-chairman of the independent Golos election monitoring group. “The government can de facto agitate for a yes vote with their campaign literature, but activists campaigning for a no vote are being arrested as we speak.” There have been several early reports of manipulations. Some of the claims related to age-old techniques: for example, evidence of forced voting at large enterprises, where vulnerable, low-paid workers are asked to vote under management supervision. But there were examples of newer tricks too. Earlier this month, a reporter at the liberal Dozhd television network exposed a fraudulent scheme that registered the details of pensioners on electronic voting websites, with the aim of then voting on their behalf. The reporter was summoned by state investigators for his trouble. In the early hours of Thursday morning, another reporter for the same channel managed to vote twice — electronically and in person. That reporter would be fined 30,000 roubles (£350), election authorities confirmed. No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe wide array of voting methods being employed during the week-long vote will make assessing its fairness difficult. Not only is electronic voting possible in two cities – Moscow and Niznny Novgorod – but mobile voting at home and at work is being allowed without extenuating circumstances for the first time. There will be limited scope for independent oversight monitors will only be permitted from regional isions of the Public Chamber, a quasi-governmental organisation. “The vote is deliberately being held in the grey zone,” says Mr Melkonyants. “Those who want to cheat have a huge number of options, and it will be impossible to catch them.” Authorities at all levels, and across Russia’s 11 time zones, understand the importance of securing good numbers for the president. Acceptable figures vary “according to the levels of cynicism” of inidual actors, says Tatyana Stanovaya, director of political analysis firm RPolitik. For some, like Moscow’s mayor, Sergei Sobyanin, the target for yes votes is likely 70 per cent. For others, like Chechen president, Ramzan Kadyrov, the target will be nearer 100 per cent. “Overall, there is a sense that any result below 65 per cent would be a bad result,” Ms Stanovaya suggests.It seems a stretch to believe that the president would reach those figures in an entirely free election. A recent poll by the independent Levada Centre indicated that of those who were sure they would vote, 55 per cent would support the presidential amendments. But that figure drops below 50 per cent when it takes in all voters. Another poll by the same organisation suggested that just 25 per cent of Russians would vote for the amendments if they had a chance to vote for alternatives. Levada Centre is not the only polling organisation to register a haemorrhaging of support away from Russia’s president over recent years. How 20 years of Putin has shaped Russia and the worldAt the peak of his ratings, a year after the annexation of Crimea in June 2015, Mr Putin was supported by nine out of every 10 Russians. The same “closed” question elicits a positive answer from only 59 per cent today, and just 8 per cent of youngsters. In open polling, where respondents are asked to name the politicians they most trust for themselves – in what is considered most indicative of a free choice – Mr Putin was named by just 29 per cent of Russians. Sociologists at Levada registered the biggest falls following Mr Putin’s decision to push through unpopular pension reforms in 2018. Ms Stanovaya, however, traces the roots of an erosion of trust to 2017, when focus groups began to indicate growing disillusionment with the Kremlin’s focus on foreign campaigns in Syria and Ukraine.“The new challenges of the pandemic, low oil prices, and the constitution are catalysts for a process of erosion that began much earlier,” she says. Judging by the rush to get the vote done in the face of the pandemic, the fear among many in power would seem to be that the position is about to get even worse. “This is essentially a special operation from Putin, and special operations are all about reducing risks and mobilising quickly,” says Ms Stanovaya. “Waiting until the autumn would have meant inviting instability, the risk of a second coronavirus wave and social unrest that no one really knows how to deal with.” Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: opening pubs but not schools doesnt add up
story: PRAISE the Lord – the decision is made. You can now at last be within ft in of someone outside your immediate household! What’s more, from July , you will be able to eat in restaurants, have a drink and, of course, continue shopping.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWhat you won’t be able to do, unless you are very fortunate, is to get your children into school, which says something about our national priorities. Make no mistake about it, this is a “national emergency”. Education should have the upfront priority that we rightly give the NHS and saving our economy. The failure since the beginning of March to plan ahead for getting all schools and all youngsters back into the classroom has been reprehensible.I say all schools because the majority have been open for the children of key workers and for children designated as vulnerable.Many teachers have been doing a first-class job trying to keep in touch with children at home, providing them with online tuition, homework and marking. But there is still time to mobilise all the necessary resources to make it possible to get children back to school for at least a couple of weeks before the end of this term.Yes, it would involve finding extra premises for schools with inadequate space. Yes, we would have to appeal to teachers who have recently retired to come back for perhaps a few hours a week. Yes, we would need to employ supply teachers.In addition we could use university students, who won’t be finding summer jobs any time soon, to assist.Of course, we don’t have that reliable summer weather that will allow teaching outside on a regular basis, butDenmark can place many lessons in an outside setting, we can.If the French, Lord help us, can get their schools mobilised and back to full operation, we can. Their trade unions are far more bolshy than ours, and teachers regrettably much less well paid.So we need a combination of creativity, imagination and drive to get pupils back. We need to rebuild the confidence of parents and staff that they are highly unlikely to contract the virus from the children, or of the children passing it on to each other.That way, we can have ironed out the glitches and be ready in September to be absolutely on the ball. Small group tutoring for recovery programmes, mentoring not just organised centrally, but co-ordinated locally.For anyone who doesn’t believe that two or three weeks matter in terms of education, when children have been out of school since the middle of March, then think again. This is about equality, narrowing the gap between the haves and have-nots, and opening a window on the world. But it is also more than that. It’s a place of social interaction, of well-being and of safety. Don’t take my word for it. Take the word of the Royal College of Paediatricians, the people whose whole le is spent on the well-being of children. They are very clear: Schools must , children need each other as well as their teachers.The recognition of the importance of schools was something I was proud to oversee in , when the incoming government’s priority slogan was, “education, education, education”.Don’t get me wrong. The belated announcement last week of a one per cent uplt for all schools and a £million pot for an online recovery programme is extremely welcome. A pity, therefore, that in making a really great announcement, the Government managed not to put any money aside for the  to -year-olds in further education, who are surely the target group we would want to be helping the most.So, thank you to all those who have done everything they can to keep the wheels on the cart over the past dficult three and a half months. But now we need both national leadership and local organisation. To use an old adage, we need to think national but we need to act local. Education trusts, local authorities, teachers’ unions and all those committed to the future of this nation should want to come together to make it work.In the next ten days, while the Government thinks about its advice, others can get on with the job. Take what is working best and spread it.What can work in France or Denmark or Germany can certainly work here. We are not out of the woods yet, but we can take logical, rational and brave decisions. That is what leadership is all about.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry shaped hole happy royal family
story: To the rest of us, it’s a charming exception to the more formal royal photos of old.But how was it received by the person who’s so obviously missing from this image of paternal closeness . . .  Prince Harry Since a spokesman confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex would be inactive on their @sussexroyal Instagram account from Aprilthere’s no way of knowing whether Harry would have publicly thanked his father last Sunday or , indeed, he has done so in private.But given that he’s reportedly homesick for the UK, this photo — taken in December — must have prompted a visceral longing for home. How could it not The sense of countryside and fresh air it evokes, the tweed caps, the fingerless mittens, the ornate walking stick . . .  just the innate Britishness of it all. Such a far cry from the smog, red carpets, bling and supercars of LA.And then, of course, it’s a reminder of the people he’s known since birth.Those who, unlike the “mwah mwah”, showbiz crowd, love him for who, rather than what, he is.Whichever way you view his behaviour of late, it’s undeniable that there is a huge, Harry-shaped hole in this image of family togetherness.Of course, there are Zoom meetings to be had and, post-lockdown, the occasional visit to be made. But it’s never quite the same.And therein lies the rub when you marry someone from another country.At first your initial attraction and then love for each other transcends geographical or cultural dferences.But when children come along and you’re required to stay in one place, inevitably one of you has to give up more than the other.Meghan tried it, albeit for a very short time, and now Harry is the one living thousands of miles away from his family and the only le he’s ever known.He made the decision to step down as a senior royal and decamp to the US for the sake of his new family — Meghan and Archie — but that doesn’t make it any less tough to see the old one ticking over nicely without him.A couple of years ago, I was in a central London restaurant with a group of other married couples and, much to the annoyance of we wives, the husbands couldn’t take their eyes off a woman sitting at the bar.Wearing the shortest of dresses, her legs were encircled around the object of her affections and her tongue made frequent visits to his ear.I recognised the man as actor Stephen Campbell Moore, ex-husband of The Crown star Claire Foy, and his obviously smitten companion as Sophie Cookson, who played Christine Keeler in last year’s BBC drama about the Profumo scandal.Fast forward to lockdown and this photo, suggests the couple may now be expecting their first child.The fond arrival of which will mean a heavy-hearted goodbye to those late-night, lust-filled liaisons that had the rest of us drooling with envy.Kaiser Chiefs frontman Ricky Wilson says he amuses himself by lying in interviews then changing his Wikipedia page to match his inventions.It reminds me of my stint as a royal correspondent when, after days of being on the road together, we would challenge each other to use silly names in stories.Hence, “Toby Lerone” was quoted in an article filed from the royals’ favourite ski resort in Switzerland, and in another story to do with Italy, “Sam Buca” made an appearance.Daft, I know, but it amused usno one .Mr Pendragon, who refuses to pay to park, says they stopped him from leaving his car on nearby roads.Shouldn’t he have been on horseback Bored by St Tropez, billionaires are reportedly snapping up “expedition yachts” that will take them to more adventurous corners of the globe.The one owned by US billionaire Ray Dalio has three deep-ing submersibles, and converted former Soviet spy boat Olivia is currently on the market for £million.Back home, lock-down quarantine rules have forced a  per cent rise in multi-millionaire Brits splashing their cash on vast private pools.Meanwhile, the rest of us will make do with a boat in the bath and a paddling pool.Sarah Ferguson – aka Prince Andrew’s ex we – is building up quite a following on her YouTube channel, where she reads children’s books such as The Wonky Donkey and Little Red Riding Hood while wearing fancy dress.Her success is no surprise, because on the many occasions I’ve seen her at charity events, she always connects brilliantly with the children in attendance.But personally, I can’t wait for her to get round to the critically acclaimed Idan Hadari book about a boy who wants to be famous.It’s called Andrew’s Claim To Fame.Or, in the Duke of York’s case, should that be infamy Yep. She now looks about .When -year-old Khairi Saadallah started his alleged kne rampage in a Reading park, a young, off-duty police officer ran towards the danger and rugby tackled him to the ground.It was a selfless act of bravery that, according to sources, saved “many more people dying”.Meanwhile, a judge has praised the bravery of PC Andrew Harper, who died after being dragged along by a car as he chased some thieves.Both of these are salutary reminders that, while every police force in the world has a few bad apples, the majority of those working in law enforcement are undeniably courageous people doing a tough job that most of us would shy away from.The latest money-making exercise candle from Gwyneth Paltrow is called This Smells Like My Orgasm.Which, as you ask, is “tart grapefruit, neroli, and ripe cassis berries blended with gunpowder tea and Turkish rose absolutes”. Er, right.Like its highly successful predecessor This Smells Like My Vagina candle – which, for the blissfully unaware, is “geranium, citrusy bergamot, and cedar absolutes juxtaposed with Damask rose and ambrette seed” – it costs£.Clearly, she’s a sales genius who could flog underwear to a nudist, but one suspects any attempt to branch out with a, to put it politely, Smells Like My Winkle range might prove a tougher sell.Hmmm. While the new name — Lost The Pot Noodle — is inspired, one notes that it now requires the consumer to put the ingredients in a mug or make it in a pan on the stove.As any self-respecting, Olympically idle student will tell you, a clean mug is a rarer sighting than an eclipse and, as for a pan, eventhey own one it will be housing enough penicillin growth to solve America’s recent shortage.So, memo to Unilever: Don’t phase out the original just yet.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stay half in half out of lockdown well be happier
story: LOCKDOWN is pretty much over. The Prime Minister announced that we were at last allowed out of our Great British Hibernation.We can go to the pub, buy useless tat in shops and queue up for plaster lawn ornaments from garden centres. We can have the in-laws round to visit! Yoot!⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBoris says that his decision was made on good scientic advice. Hmm, maybe. It is true that the infection rate for Covid has been dropping rapidly for some time. But it’s still there, still hanging around with mischief on its mind. All it takes is one person in a gathering of  or  at some pizza joint and that infection rate will be up again quickly enough.In some of the countries that have released their people from lockdown, a second spike has occurred.In Germany the famous “R” rate for infection is well above the dreaded one. South Korea and Spain have seen new outbreaks, too.But the truth is Boris didn’t have much of an option. The public is bored stf and the economy is wrecked.I suspect the decision was arrived at on those grounds, rather than strictly on the science. Everyone wants to go out and spend money. I am not sure why they do.  There were good things about lockdown — and it taught us one or two truths about ourselves.It was a pleasure to hear the birds singing, for example. A real delight to see the roads free from traffic. The skies are full of swts and swallows instead of the incessant airline flights. The quality of the air we breathe improved hugely as a result. So did the water quality of rivers and streams.We went out much, much less. As a consequence, many people saved an awful lot of money because they weren’t wasting it on buying rubbish from shops.People learned to cook — and ate home-prepared meals with their families. The truth is, in normal times, we eat out far more often than is good for us, financially or otherwise. And we shopped locally — the corner stores did a roaring trade — and less often, thus saving carbon emissions.Employers discovered that people could work from home perfectly well. Hopefully this will persuade some to scale back their offices and give people the chance to work from home.Imagine how many homes could be created from disused offices! We wouldn’t have to pave over half the country to sort out our housing crisis. Imagine cutting out the daily commute for ever!We didn’t have to hug people. Indeed, we were barred by law from hugging people. Or kissing them on the bloody cheek, like everyone in the media world does. That, by itself, was a huge bonus for me.My wish is that we take some of that stuff from lockdown and make it the new normal. Live at a quieter, gentler pace. Continue to eat at home — and support our local corner shops. Use the car less. Spend less money on a whole load of b******s we don’t really need. Use aeroplanes not at all, preferably. Right now, the Government has given us licence to go out and do stuff.Here’s my plea. Let’s do a bit less stuff than we used to. Let’s remain kind of half in and half out of lockdown. Whether Covid is still around or not. We’ll end up happier as a result.ONE thing Captain Tom showed us, as he walked around his garden as he approached the age of , is that it’s never too late to make a dference.Bob Dylan is just a young whippersnapper by Tom’s standards.But at the age of  he has just made his finest album in at least three decades, and probably more. Rough And Rowdy Ways is a joy to listen to – and I’d given up on the bloke in the s.If I ever reach  I intend to make a grime album with Rihanna. Get your orders in now.The United Nations has decided to give them to Mauritius. That’s because the islands are nearer Mauritius than they are to the UK. On that basis we could have a good claim to owning Belgium. The islands are important to the UK militarily. And we should keep them. The UN has given us deadlines to hand them over to a country that never owned them. What we should do instead is leave the crooked UN.EXCLUDED from the Government’s loosening of lockdown are Britain’s vibrant community of werewolves and vampires.“It is all very well biting someone’s neck, or ripping their lungs out while howling loudly,” a scientist advising the Government probably said. “But when they do this there is the risk that the virus could be passed on via droplets from the creature’s mouth. Or indeed paws – werewolves do not have a good record of using hand-sanitiser.”By contrast, zombies were praised for their social-distancing technique. “Whenever you see them they are always walking two metres apart with their hands outstretched and bits of flesh falling off their faces,” the same scientist probably added.A spokesman for the National Association of Lycanthropescommented: “This is typical of the prejudice we werewolves face and amounts to discrimination. Actually, I thought I had the virus a few weeks ago. Nasty cough and so on.“But I’m all right nooooowwwwwwooooo.”THE day after the woke ninnies at Warners withdrew the great Hollywood film Gone With The Wind because of “race issues”, guess what happened  Yup, it became the No bestselling film on Amazon. Better still, it reached No in the AppleiTunes chart for TV and film. Not bad for a movie made more than  years ago, huh I suppose it could have been “progressives” buying the film so that they would have something to be outraged about. Or maybe the Ku Klux Klan Film Club has a bigger membership than we thought.More likely though is that people loathe censorship. They don’t like being told what they can and can’t watch. Truth be told it hasn’t been for a good  years. And the process accelerated under Magic Grandpa and his front bench of mouth-breathing dingbats. Now it’s the well-orf who support Labour. And the poor who vote Conservative. But there aren’t enough people called Olly and Poppy in the country, which is why Labour hasn’t won an election for  years. Unless it reconnects with the people it was set up to support, the working class, it won’t win one for another few decades either.A SOCIAL media site had a big hit when it asked people to reveal things they regretted about getting married. The site, Whisper, was inundated with replies. Most were kind of: “I just wish I hadn’t married the fat bastard, full stop.”But some wished they’d had a fling with someone of the same sex first, or felt aggrieved they hadn’t checked out the in-laws first. That was quite a big issue. I wonder how many marriages fail because of the families each side marries into GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: music britain collapsing covid 19
story: And now I’m scratching my head wondering how cinemas are able to welcome visitors before we’ve worked out how to listen to music together.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesLive music is vital, not just for fuelling our dreams but for the reality of our economy, too.The live music sector is expecting to suffer £million in losses this year, which is  per cent of its annual contribution to the UK economy.From arena concerts to your local pub singer, ALL live music has been silenced.But the Government doesn’t seem to be taking it seriously, with music way down the list of priorities and no date in the diary for when we will be able to go to a gig again.We can’t afford to take our music scene for granted.Since the birth of rock ’n’ roll, Britain has dominated global tastes in pop music.Part of The Beatles’ legacy is that they transformed the British record business from a cottage industry into a global phenomenon.When they signed to Parlophone, early in the Sixties, one man and his secretary ran the entire label.George Martin signed the band, produced, manufactured and promoted their early records and, over the brief course of the band’s existence, saw the whole thing go through the roof.It was comparable to the dotcom boom or internet shopping.Many now see the Rolling Stones as the greatest band to come out of that era for the way they have managed to continue playing to vast new audiences  years later.But the Sixties was just the start of it. The Seventies brought Led Zeppelin and countless rock bands, it gave us heavy metal and punk and Joy Division pretty much all at the same time.The biggest-selling album of the Eighties, Michael Jackson’s Thriller, was actually written by a bloke from Hull, while British greats as erse as Duran Duran and The Smiths ruled the waves.In the Cool Britannia of the Nineties, when Britpop was ringing out of radio networks worldwide, even American stars such as Madonna sought help from British producers such as Nellee Hooper and William Orbit.Then there were the Spice Girls. And Coldplay. Now we’ve got Ed Sheeran and Adele. And it doesn’t stop with artists. Love him or hate him, Simon Cowell’s TV programmes are another British global music phenomenon.But it’s live music where Britain really dominates today. Glastonbury should be taking place this weekend.I’ve played at just about every major festival on the planet, from Coachella in the US to Fuji Rock in Japan, but there is nowhere to touch Glastonbury.It is, quite simply, the greatest show on earth There is a massive ripple effect from Glastonbury. It sets a very high bar for the other  — that’s  — festivals that happen throughout the UK every single summer.And the same crews who build the stages, operate the sound systems, put up the fences and supply the bogs for Glasto are busy for the rest of the summer at other events.Now the independent festival sector is at risk of collapse thanks to the Covid shutdown.Last month, the Association of Independent Festivals , which represents  festivals in the UK, reported that  per cent of its members were facing costs that could ruin their businesses and . per cent were uninsured for Covid- related cancellations.Most of my time these days is spent planning and organising The Big Feastival, which was due to take place here on my farm in Oxfordshire this August Bank Holiday weekend.Of course I’m devastated it won’t be going ahead, but the really sad thing is that it looks like no one is going to hear any live music, new or old this summer.That’s a tragedy for the musicians who rely on gigging to make a living — as well as all the other people whose income relies on live music.The Musicians’ Union says its members have lost more than £million in income during the lockdown. Remember, that most musicians just scrape by at the best of times.Big stars are bigger than ever before, but they are the exception not the rule. When Adele releases another record there is a danger she will become so massive she will collapse into a black hole.But now bands need an audience to play to and also financial support, which used to come from record companies but now is hard to find.Records, or downloads, are basically free these days, so live shows are the only real way to make money.In the same way restaurants were already struggling before lockdown, many of Britain’s smaller live music venues were struggling too.So most of the places I played in the early days with Blur have already dis- appeared. They need to be able to open their doors again, as do festivals.It has to be possible to find a way. Just as with pubs, restaurants and cinemas, you could limit the number of people allowed into a venue.Perhaps more gigs could be seated to ensure social distancing. Not quite the same, but better than nothing.As far as the rest of the planet is concerned, Britain is represented pretty much by the Royal Family, football and music.We must keep our festival circuit alive and nurture new artists.That means we urgently have to find a way for music to be played to a live audience, evenit’s only a small one — so that we can keep meaning something to the rest of the world.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unions betrayed our kids
story: Its Headmaster Ben Hulme used his imagination, created extra space on the school field and put other hygiene measures in place.Now, to the delight of parents, almost all his pupils started back on Monday. And that’s with the two-metre rule.Yes, it’s easier with a small school. But his determination to do what is right by the children made the real dference.Contrast that with the union militants and council leaders of the Left. Although the Government could have done better in prioritising education, the wrecking crew have revelled in  confronting and defying the Tories, blocking efforts to reopen fully.Even now, the PM’s announcement that schools must open in September is branded “pure fantasy” by one union.We do not yet know the true cost to our children’s education, le chances and health from this failure of will. The unions have betrayed our kids and tarnished the image of the teachers they represent and who would love to get back to the classroom.PUBS with no music, singing, dancing or shouting  That’s just a library with more beer and no books.And how about visor-clad hairdressers snipping in enforced silence, with no gossip or radio It all sounds like a sci-fi dystopia of Britain. But this is the Government’s vision for our summer as it tries to save businesses while keeping us safe.To which we say: Well, good luck with that. We understand the reasoning. The scientists say all these activities pass on Covid in the breath. And they are desperate to avoid a new surge in cases.Some might see little point in a pub with the le sucked out of it. But we must use them or lose them.From July , support your local. Consider it your solemn duty.THE survey saying a quarter of furloughed workers will lose their jobs is horrying.Nine million are being kept afloat by the bailout. But that ruinous cost will end. At which point more than two million will be added to the dole queue.That will be a bitter blow for many who have enjoyed the lockdown — some packing the beaches yesterday on what would ordinarily be a working day.The bailouts’ end in October spells devastation in particular for the young and low-paid. And it falls to Chancellor Rishi Sunak to recreate the jobs boom of the last decade.At least, post-Brexit, he will have even more tools with which to do it.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: monkeys apes thailand lopburi
story: Locals in the city of Lopburi say the macaques primates are running rampant because the lack of tourism caused by the coronavirus lockdown has left the feral beasts starved of food.Residents have tried to help the creatures by feeding them junk food, but it is feared the sugary diet has made them sex crazed and breeding faster than before, it has been reported.Now, a sterilisation plan by authorities is underway as locals look to take back control of the streets.Before coronavirus, the humans and the primates used to live together peacefully with the monkey population believed to be as high as ,.But since the regular food supply from tourists dried up and the streets emptied, locals talk of a city where the small creatures are running riot. Local woman Kuljira Taechawattanawanna told the Daily Mail it was like being in prison: We live in a cage but the monkeys live outside.Despite the animals being outnumbered by the , humans living there, parts of the city are said to now be no-go zones. According to witnesses, the animals have turned an abandoned cinema into their headquarters where they also leave the remains of their dead love ones.Any human who attempts to enter is reportedly attacked.Residents had resorted to giving the monkeys sweets, fizzy drinks and cereal - but now fear the sugary treats have made them more hyper and sexually-active.Drastic action is now being taken by authorities who have restarted a sterilisation this month after a three-year pause. Wildle department officers plan to lure the creatures into cages and take them to a clinic, where they will be sedated, sterilised and left with a tattoo to mark their neutering. They aim to neuter  of them by Friday.It is thought there may be some pushback from residents who have grown accustomed to the monkeys, despite the problems they have caused recently. Taweesak Srisaguan, a shop owner who uses stuffed toy animals to try and scare the horde away, is wary of them disappearing completely. He said: Im used to seeing them walking around, playing on the street.If theyre all gone, Id definitely be lonely.Narongporn Daudduem from the wildle department acknowledges locals will have to give their consent. We need to do a survey of the people living in the area first.Its like dumping garbage in front of their houses and asking themtheyre happy or not.The primate presence in Lopburi previously came under the spotlight in March when a mass brawl over a single banana went viral. title: olive morris google doodle activist
story: She dedicated her le to the struggle for liberation, democracy and equality and is considered a key figure in the campaign for change.Born " href"https:artsandculture.google story XwWReHwADexA eStellaAccess" target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"Olive Elaine Morris in June  in St Catherine, Jamaica, she became prominent during the s for her activism in London and Manchester.Morris moved to London, England when she was nine to join her parents, who migrated there as part of the Windrush generation.A community activist in South London in the s, Morris dedicated her le to fighting for racial, gender and social equality.Morris joined the British Black Panther Youth movement in  and was a key member alongside Linton Kwesi Johnson, Althea Johnson, Neil Kenlock and Clovis Reid.At Manchester Univeristy she studied social sciences and was an active member of the Manchester Black Women’s Cooperative.Sadly, she died of cancer aged  in .Google Doodle is celebrating Morris on June  - what would have been her th birthday. Her legacy is evident in Brixton, as she helped found the Brixton Black Women’s Group, one of Britain’s first networks for Black women, in .Morris also co-founded the Organisation of Women of Asian and African Descent, considered instrumental in rallying movements for change. She was a feminist, committed to the fight against racial, sexual and class oppression.Morris participated in the squatter campaign in the s, opening the  Railton Road squat in  with Liz Obi.Historians remember Morris for her passion for issues such as housing, womens rights and the struggle against racial discrimination. In , Google founders Larry and Sergey drew a stick figure behind the second o of Google to show they were out of office at the Burning Man festival and with that, Google Doodles were born.The company decided that they should decorate the logo to mark cultural moments and it soon became clear that users really enjoyed the change to the Google homepage.Now, there is a full team of doodlers, illustrators, graphic designers, animators and classically trained artists who help create what you see on those days.In  so far theyve had Doodles Scottish astrophysicist genius Mary Somerville and Aids activist Nkosi Johnson, who died aged .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
